Recommended new audiobooks for children #1

Written by Sophie Green · Published Sep 21, 2017

CD audiobooks

The Everything Machine, by Ally Kennen, read by Joe Coen

‚ÄúEleven-year-old Olly has a very special delivery - a 3D printing machine, stamped with PROPERTY OF M.O.D and BRITISH SPACE AGENCY. WARNING. DO NOT TAMPER, which has magical powers. It has a name, it speaks, and it can print ANYTHING Olly asks it to - a never-ending supply of sweets, a swimming pool in the shed - but what Olly really wants is his dad, who has separated from his mum and moved out of the family home. Cue the creation of Dad-Bot - he looks just like Dad (on a good day) but is totally chaotic - and his antics tip Olly and co into a heart-racing and heart-warming adventure!‚Äù

The Secret Kitten, by Holly Webb, read by Victoria Fox

‚ÄúLucy can‚Äôt help but feel lonely when she and her brother move in with their gran, leaving behind their old school and friends. Lucy wishes she could have a pet, but Gran isn‚Äôt keen on animals. A black and white stray kitten catches Lucy‚Äôs attention, and she instantly falls in love with it. But she is upset when she reads in a magazine that the kitten‚Äôs colour will make it difficult to rehome. Too young to look after herself, where will the kitten go if she can‚Äôt find anyone to take her in?‚Äù

Strange Star, by Emma Carroll, read by Victoria Fox

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a stormy night in 1816 when there‚Äôs a knock at the door of Villa Diodati. Lying in the rain is a dead girl, and with her, lots of questions. Like, why did she come? What was she looking for? And who was she running from?‚Äù

Attack of the Alien Dung!, by Gareth P. Jones, read by David Thorpe

‚ÄúBiskit works alone. So when the unruly Pet Defenders canine agent is teamed up with Mitzy - a rookie and, even worse, a cat - he‚Äôs not happy. Can Biskit put his ego aside and join forces with Mitzy to save the world from an alien attack of terrifying proportions?‚Äù

OverDrive

Set up OverDrive

White Fang, by Jack London, read by John Lee

‚ÄúIn the desolate, frozen wilds of northwest Canada, a wolf cub finds himself the sole survivor of his litter. Son of Kiche, half-wolf, half-dog, and the ageing wolf One Eye, he is thrust into a savage world where each day renews the struggle of survival. It is a lonely but noble life‚Äîuntil the day he is captured by dog-driving men. The cruel mistreatment he bears in this new life of slavery teaches him to hate.

‚ÄúOnly one man sees beyond the rage of White Fang to his intelligence and dignity. Only one has the courage to offer the killer a new life. But can his kindness reach the heart of White Fang?‚Äù

Skulduggery Pleasant: playing with fire, by Derek Landy, read by Rupert Degas

‚ÄúJust when you think you‚Äôve saved the world‚Ä¶

"‚ÄùYou will kill her?‚Äù the Torment asked. Skulduggery sagged. ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù He hesitated, then took his gun from his jacket. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, Valkyrie,‚Äù he said softly. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt talk to me,‚Äù Valkyrie said. ‚ÄúJust do what you have to do.‚Äù Valkyrie parted her tunic, and Skulduggery pointed the gun at the vest beneath. ‚ÄúPlease forgive me,‚Äù Skulduggery said, then aimed the gun at the girl and pulled the trigger.

‚ÄúWith Serpine dead, the world is safe once more. At least, that‚Äôs what Valkyrie and Skulduggery think, until the notorious Baron Vengeous makes a bloody escape from prison, and dead bodies and vampires start showing up all over Ireland. With Baron Vengeous after the deadly armour of Lord Vile, and pretty much everyone out to kill Valkyrie, the daring detective duo face their biggest challenge yet. But what if the greatest threat to Valkyrie is just a little closer to home?‚Äù

BorrowBox

Set up BorrowBox

The Tale of Angelino Brown, by David Almond, read by Malcolm Hamilton

‚ÄúBert and Betty Brown have got themselves a little angel. Bert found him in his top pocket when he was driving his bus.

‚ÄúBert and Betty‚Äôs friends think he‚Äôs lovely. So do Nancy and Jack and Alice from Class 5K. What a wonder!

‚ÄúBut Acting Head Teacher Mrs Mole is not so sure. Nor is Professor Smellie, or the mysterious bloke in black who claims to be a School Inspector.

‚ÄúThen there‚Äôs Basher Malone ‚Äì big, lumbering Basher Malone. He REALLY doesn‚Äôt like Angelino. And it looks like he‚Äôs out to get him‚Ä¶‚Äù

Pottymouth and Stoopid, by James Patterson and Chris Grabenstein, read by Scott Connolly

‚ÄúDavid and his best friend Michael were tagged with awful nicknames way back in preschool when everyone did silly things. Fast-forward to seventh grade: ‚ÄòPottymouth‚Äô and ‚ÄòStoopid‚Äô are still stuck with the names ‚Äì and everyone in school, including the teachers and their principal, believe the labels are true.

‚ÄúSo how do they go about changing everyone‚Äôs minds? By turning their misery into megastardom on TV, of course! Follow their roller-coaster journey from the ultimate losers to the biggest winners.

‚ÄúThis important story delivers more than just laughs ‚Äì it shows that the worst bullying doesn‚Äôt have to be physical, and that things will get better.‚Äù

Sophie Green

I work for the Suffolk Libraries stock team. I also write children‚Äôs fiction, short stories and comedy. Visit my website.
